user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_SetDataBuffer:
```c
void UT_SetDataBuffer(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, void *DataBuffer, size_t BufferSize, bool AllocateCopy)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr;

    if (DataBuffer != NULL && BufferSize > 0)
    {
        StubPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED);

        if (StubPtr == NULL)
        {
            UtAssert_Abort("Cannot set data buffer - UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS too low?");
        }
        else
        {
            StubPtr->FuncKey   = FuncKey;
            StubPtr->EntryType = UT_ENTRYTYPE_DATA_BUFFER;
            if (AllocateCopy)
            {
                StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr = malloc(BufferSize);
                if (StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr == NULL)
                {
                    UtAssert_Abort("Cannot allocate data buffer - malloc() failed!");
                }
                else
                {
                    memcpy(StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr, DataBuffer, BufferSize);
                    StubPtr->ModeFlags |= UT_MODEFLAG_ALLOC_BUF;
                }
            }
            else
            {
                /* Use buffer directly */
                StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr = DataBuffer;
            }
            StubPtr->Data.Buff.TotalSize = BufferSize;
            StubPtr->Data.Buff.Position  = 0;
        }
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UT_SetDataBuffer:
static UT_StubTableEntry_t *UT_GetStubEntry(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, UT_EntryType_t TestMode)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr   = NULL;
    uint32               Idx       = FuncKey % (UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS - 1); /* hash the key to determine the start point */
    uint32               SearchLen = 0;
    uint32               SearchLimit;
    UT_EntryKey_t        SearchKey;

    /* If searching for an unused entry, look through the entire table.
     * Otherwise bound the search */
    if (TestMode == UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED)
    {
        SearchLimit = UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS;
        SearchKey   = 0;
    }
    else
    {
        SearchLimit = UT_MaxStubSearchLen;
        SearchKey   = FuncKey;
    }

    while (1)
    {
        if (SearchLen >= SearchLimit)
        {
            StubPtr = NULL;
            break;
        }
        ++SearchLen;
        StubPtr = &UT_StubTable[Idx];
        if (StubPtr->EntryType == TestMode && StubPtr->FuncKey == SearchKey)
        {
            break;
        }
        ++Idx;
        if (Idx >= UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS)
        {
            Idx = 0;
        }
    }

    /*
     * Keep track of the longest search length since the last reset.
     * This serves as the upper bound for future searches.
     */
    if (SearchLen > UT_MaxStubSearchLen)
    {
        UT_MaxStubSearchLen = SearchLen;
    }

    return StubPtr;
}
...
void UtAssert_Abort(const char *Message)
{
    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT, Message);
}
...
void UT_BSP_DoText(uint8 MessageType, const char *OutputMessage)
{
    char   Buffer[16];
    size_t MsgLen;
    uint32 TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL;
    uint32 MsgEnabled   = BSP_UT_Global.CurrVerbosity >> MessageType;

    if (MsgEnabled & 1)
    {
        UT_BSP_Lock();

        /* Determine if the message type warrants special treatment (color/highlight/etc). */
        switch (MessageType)
        {
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT:
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FAILURE:
                TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_RED;
                break;
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_MIR:
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_WARN:
                TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_RED | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_GREEN;
                break;
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TSF:
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TTF:
                TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_RED | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_BLUE;
                break;
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_BEGIN:
                OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl("\n", 1); /* add a bit of extra whitespace between tests */
                break;
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_PASS:
                TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_GREEN;
                break;
            default:
                break;
        }

        if (MsgEnabled <= 1)
        {
            TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL;
        }

        snprintf(Buffer, sizeof(Buffer), "[%5s]", UtAssert_GetCaseTypeAbbrev(MessageType));

        if (TermModeBits != OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL)
        {
            OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl(TermModeBits);
        }

        OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(Buffer, strlen(Buffer));

        if (TermModeBits != OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL)
        {
            OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl(OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL);
        }

        OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(" ", 1);
        MsgLen = strlen(OutputMessage);
        OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(OutputMessage, MsgLen);
        if (MsgLen == 0 || OutputMessage[MsgLen - 1] != '\n')
        {
            OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl("\n", 1);
        }

        UT_BSP_Unlock();
    }

    /*
     * If any ABORT (major failure) message is thrown,
     * then call a BSP-provided routine to stop the test and possibly dump a core
     */
    if (MessageType == UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT)
    {
        OS_BSP_Shutdown_Impl();
    }
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
The remaining symbols and calls in the provided code do not themselves indicate recursion and therefore do not need separate investigation here:

- Standard library calls (malloc, memcpy, snprintf, strlen) are library routines and are not expected to call back into these unit-test framework functions; they do not introduce indirect recursion in the shown code.
- The low-level BSP/hardware hooks referenced (OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl, OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl, OS_BSP_Shutdown_Impl), UT_BSP_Lock/UT_BSP_Unlock, and UtAssert_GetCaseTypeAbbrev are external/implementation-specific. Their implementations are not present in the supplied code; whether they cause indirect recursion can only be determined by inspecting their actual definitions. Because they are not defined in the provided fragments, they cannot be included as code fragments here — instead, their implementations should be inspected separately if recursion is suspected.
- Data structures and globals referenced (UT_StubTable, UT_MaxStubSearchLen, BSP_UT_Global, UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS, mode flags, etc.) are passive in the shown fragments and do not by themselves create call cycles.

Therefore the investigation should focus on the four reported functions and, separately, on the implementations of the external BSP hooks if available, to determine any indirect call paths that could lead back to these functions.
